content: Getting a little confused by the dihedral group definition and what r and sr are... these *facts* here don't seem to line up with the ones on wikipedia (yah not a great source ik). Are the ones on wikipedia incorrect or referring to different things... image.png. In mathlib dihedral_group.r i * dihedral_group.sr j = dihedral_group.sr (j - i) whereas wikipedia states r^i * s^j=s^{i+j}?

These formulas depend on how you define s_j. If we take the "standard" presentation to be
D2n=⟨r,s ∣ rn=s2=(rs)2=1⟩D_{2n} = \langle r,s \ | \ r^n = s^2 = (rs)^2 = 1 \rangleD2n​=⟨r,s ∣ rn=s2=(rs)2=1⟩
and define rj=rjr_j = r^jrj​=rj and sj=rj⋅ss_j = r^j \cdot ssj​=rj⋅s, then we would have ri⋅sj=si+jr_i \cdot s_j = s_{i+j}ri​⋅sj​=si+j​.

But if we define sj=s⋅rjs_j = s \cdot r^jsj​=s⋅rj then we would have ri⋅sj=ri⋅s⋅rj=s⋅rj−i=sj−ir_i \cdot s_j = r_i \cdot s \cdot r^j = s \cdot r^{j-i} = s_{j-i}ri​⋅sj​=ri​⋅s⋅rj=s⋅rj−i=sj−i​.
It's all just a question of what you mean by the "j-th" reflection and the "i-th" rotation. You can parameterize these things in different ways.

hmm never seen that chevron construction for the dihedrals before...
So does the mathlib def sr i mean a reflection then a rotation of i? Both wikipedia and mathlib say that s or sr is a "reflection".

Also what is the difference between rir_iri​ and rir^iri...?
What is your definition of D_{2n}?
the dihedral group... wait you can define the D2nD_{2n}D2n​ in different ways...
There are loads of ways to define it, which is why your question is so hard to understand
Different definitions, especially using similar or the same notation to mean different things, can lead to confusion if you don't understand the material properly
I think I like the lean definition, where you can assume an element is either one of two variants.

Okay, so you want to define D2nD_{2n}D2n​ as some type with 2⋅n2 \cdot n2⋅n elements, denoted
{r0,…,rn−1,s0,…,sn−1}\{r_0,\ldots,r_{n-1},s_0,\ldots,s_{n-1}\}{r0​,…,rn−1​,s0​,…,sn−1​},
but now the question is how you want to define the product!

Ben said:

So does the mathlib def sr i mean a reflection then a rotation of i?

By usual convention, where multiplication means function composition, I think it means a rotation then a reflection: when you apply a*b, b is first applied, then a.

Both wikipedia and mathlib say that s or sr is a "reflection".

Yes, in a dihedral group, the product of a reflection with a rotation (to the left or to the right) is always a reflection.

Also what is the difference between rir_iri​ and rir^iri...?

I think there's no difference.
Yah I guess it's like how Peano numbers are only one way of defining the natural numbers... didn't realise there were different forms, especially when they use the the same words and similar terms...
So the element composition definitions on wikipedia are correct, they are just using a different definition (which they don't define, just call it a reflection)
What does the s and r in the sr constructor mean in the definition on mathlib... how does it match up geometrically on a ngon?

That depends on how you're defining the group law on the n-gon. If you do reflection aaa and then reflection bbb, have you just done ababab or bababa? Both answers are "valid" in the sense that both will give you groups, but the groups won't be identical (they will be isomorphic, but the isomorphism won't be the identity function)

If you have the regular nnn-gon, centered in the plane, with a vertex on the yyy-axis, you can define rrr to be rotation counter-clockwise by 2⋅π/n2 \cdot \pi /n2⋅π/n radians (equiv. multiplication by exp⁡(2⋅π⋅i/n)\exp(2 \cdot \pi \cdot i / n)exp(2⋅π⋅i/n) in the complex plane. Also define sss to be reflection about the yyy-axis.

With these conventions, the collection of all symmetries of the regular nnn-gon are {r0,r1,…,rn−1,r0s,r1s,…,rn−1s}\{r^0,r^1,\ldots,r^{n-1},r^0s,r^1s,\ldots,r^{n-1}s\}{r0,r1,…,rn−1,r0s,r1s,…,rn−1s}. The multiplication rules follow from the formulas: rn=s2=(rs)2=1r^n = s^2 = (rs)^2 = 1rn=s2=(rs)2=1 (left as an exercise).
In this case, you can define ri=rir_i = r^iri​=ri and si=ri⋅ss_i = r^i \cdot ssi​=ri⋅s to get ri⋅sj=si+jr_i \cdot s_j = s_{i+j}ri​⋅sj​=si+j​ (arithmetic being done modulo nnn).
Adam the convention in mathlib is that sr i means srisr^isri so doing rjsr^jsrjs is only adding to the confusion.

Alternatively, note that ris=sr−ir^i s = s r^{-i}ris=sr−i so you can equivalently view D2nD_{2n}D2n​ as the set {r0,r1,…,rn−1,sr0,sr1,…,srn−1}\{r^0,r^1,\ldots,r^{n-1},sr^0,sr^1,\ldots,sr^{n-1}\}{r0,r1,…,rn−1,sr0,sr1,…,srn−1} and in this case if you define sj=srjs_j = s r^jsj​=srj then you have risj=sj−ir_i s_j = s_{j-i}ri​sj​=sj−i​.
@Kevin Buzzard yeah that's kind of the point, since wikipedia seems to use sj=rjss_j = r^j ssj​=rjs.

Oh I see, you were half way through an explanation :-) Yeah, both of these work, and interpreting them as acting on the n-gon you have to decide whether you're acting on the left or the right (or equivalently whether ababab means "do aaa then bbb" or "do bbb then aaa") which introduces yet another sign ambiguity.
as Junyan's message mentioned, the "standard" convention is that a⋅ba \cdot ba⋅b first acts by bbb then by aaa.
So for example sr2sr^2sr2 will first apply the rotation rrr twice, then apply the reflection, whereas r2sr^2sr2s will first apply sss then apply rrr twice.
So if you map r i in mathlib to rir_iri​ in Wikipedia and map sr i to sn−is_{n-i}sn−i​ ("s−is_{-i}s−i​"), you get an isomorphism between the two dihedral groups.
